body:
I checked and `poetry install` does not install rich in editable mode. In fact I do not even know what it does install as the package is not installed after:

```
ssbarnea@imac: ~/c/os/rich feature/fluidlogger ⚡
$ poetry install                                                                                                   Installing dependencies from lock file

No dependencies to install or update

  - Installing rich (8.0.0)

ssbarnea@imac: ~/c/os/rich feature/fluidlogger ⚡
$ python examples/log.py                                                                                           Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "examples/log.py", line 6, in <module>
    from rich.console import Console
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'rich.console'
FAIL: 1
```

While I do respect your option for poetry, I think that ignoring the ubiquitous pip may become a deal breaker for increasing the number of contributors (they will want editable installs) or even users (normal installs, ones that are working fine now). At this moment I have 16 packages installed in editable mode as I often contribute back to dependencies that I use tools or libraries.

My experience with poetry is quite low and after reading https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/issues/34#issuecomment-600021371 thread I got even more confused about what it does and how.


For example reading output `poetry install --help` make me realise it does not claim to install any current package at all, it mentions what would do about dependencies but nothing about the current package/project itself. Is really poetry install a replacement for pip install?
